LAVV-TRICKES OR, WHO VVOVLD HAVE THOVGHT IT.

editorialDecl.p:
The characters are identified by IDREF pointing to information in the following declarations. Horatio Lurdo Angelo Ferneze Horatio's Page Polymetes Ioculo Emily Iulio Adam Countess Winifred 1 Gentlewoman 2 Gentlewoman 3 Gentlewoman Prologue and Epilogue
combined voice

langUsage.p: The languages (other than English) which occur in the text are identified by idREF which point to the following.

div1.p: The Names of the Actors. 1 Ferneze, Duke of Genoa. Polymetes, His Sonne. Lurdo. An olde Count Horatio. A yong Count. Horatioe's. Page. Iulie. A noble youthfull Gallant. Angelo. A Noble Counsellor Adam. Scruant to Polymetes. Iocule. Page to Emilia. Emilia. Daughter to the Duke. Countesse. Lurdos wife Win. Seruant to Count Lurdo. 1 Gentlewoman. 2 Gentlewoman. 3 Gentlewoman.

div2.head: ACTUS PRIMUS.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l:
Divine invention, O how I could hug, And like an amorous Lover court thy beauty, That crownest me King of pleasures: were my brain Forged out of vulgar metal without fire, And sprightly motion, my big swollen hopes, Had been still-born, but when dejected minds, Out-slept the golden pleasure of the night: My serious meditations have out-watched, The glorious tapers that attend the Moon: I turned my thoughts into a thousand shapes: Moulded the fashion of ten thousand plots, Liked and disliked so many, that my brain The mother of Invention grew barren, Almost past bearing, still my labouring thoughts Conceived a yet more strange and quaint Idea, Gave it proportion, and I brought it forth: And that blessed infant of Invention Beyond all hope hath my contentment won, And that is Loves heaven I love a face more fair Than Cintheas hue that seems above compare,
But hell, her husband with a jealous eye Ushers her steps, O wedded slavery! This tender rose, whom artless marriage, Hath grafted on a nettle (testy age)
Have I ungrafted, made himself untie The knot of wedlock: thanks sweet industry.
And here he comes, thatwhich most heaps my fame, His wit is well spoken of.

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.l: This wit is a sprightly thing.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: For such as have it.

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.l: It not alone doth bring, Public applause, but knowledge in the law, Teacheth to speak in distance.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: How the daw Scores over his rusty phrases? honoured Count, How grows your plot?

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.l: My thriving fortunes mount Above suppose, even to my hearts content: We are divorced.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: My hopes are prevalent.

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.l: You know the cause of it, two sufficient men Swore her a harlot, and the partial Bench Inspired by my good Angels (Angels wings Sweep a clear passage to the seat of Kings) Sealed our divorce.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: But doth her brother swallow This gross abuse?

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.l:
Abuse, away, away. They know me rich Horatio, chink, chink:
Whilst this holds out, my cause shall never sink.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: See where he comes, his sad complexion wears, Griefs mourning livery, he is clothed in tears.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.l: Whence springs this sorrow?

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: For my sisters shame, My sister, O my sister, whose repute Hung like a Jewel on her sexes forehead.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.l: And what of her?

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: She is, o no she was Pure as the Diamond, clear as crystal glass, But now, O hell, her credit is more foul, Than speckled scandal, or black murders soul.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.l: I cannot think it.

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.l: But I know it too true, She was my wife and by her means, my head Was fairly tupped and you will buy a Lantern: Bespeak my sconce, it is ready horned and all.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: Not yet, but I will take order that it shall.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: And are ye parted?

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.l: What a question is that? Shall I wear cracked rings, Diamonds with a flaw, I will carry coals and you will, no horns, I know the law.

sp.speaker: An.
sp.l: Is this your grief?

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l:
This is enough, to make Patience turn ruffian, she that was the pattern,
To whose proportion all our courtly dames, Cut out their actions, she to fall: a sign ---

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.l: More will fall shortly.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: Her shame ---

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.l: Grows here, whoever broached the wine, The butt stands here, my forehead bears the sign,

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: It merits none, the shame is nor yours nor his, That foot is even made that never treads amiss, Beauty came first from Heaven, Prometheus, Stole it to make proud women beauteous, Now, stolen goods thrive not: women steal from men Then blame not them to seek their own again. Kings have for this been felons, and it is proved, He never was divine that never loved.

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.l: I find no law for this.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: Custom you prove, And what is more Ancient than to pilfer love?

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.l: A quillet well applied.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: Then bury grief, If this be felony, myself is a thief.

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.l: A nimble wit, just of the length of mine, But come my liege, forget it so will I, Our infant griefs must be old men and die,

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: Not whilst her fault survives, What news with thee.

sp.speaker: Pa.
sp.l: I bring your honour comfortable news, Your son is returned from Pisa,

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: He comes ill, And yet I hope his blessed arrive will kill This monster grief.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: He is a toward Prince.

sp.speaker: Fe.
sp.l: Toward enough, and yet most strangely weaned And wedded from this worlds society.

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.l: A parlous youth, sharpe and satirical, Would he but spend some study in the law, He would prove a passing subtle Barrister.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: He has a quick wit.

sp.speaker: Lur.
sp.l: And he speaks Latin too, Truly and so few Lawyers use to do.

div2.stage: Enter Prince Polymetes with a Booke.

sp.speaker: Poly.
sp.l: Health to this honoured presence: passing good!

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.l: Welcome sweet Prince.

sp.speaker: Poly.
sp.l: Thanks: superpassing good! But honoured father, see how he proceeds: Learning was first made pilot to the world, And in the chair of contemplation, Many degrees above the turning clouds Held in his hand the nine-leafed marble book, Drawn full of silver lines and golden Stars.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: But Son?

sp.speaker: Poly.
sp.l:
But father, it was learnings place,
Till empty outsides, shadows daubed with gold Plucked him down headlong, then he lost his wits, And ever since lives Zany to the world, Turns Pageant-Poet, toiler to the press, Makes himself cheap, detested, hist and stale, To every bubble and dull Groom. Who for his out-sides gaudy, will presume To make poor wit a hackney to his pride. And with blunt rolled Jests spur-gall his side Till his soul bleed, O, I am more than mad, To see mere shadows censure and control, The substance, worthier both in sense and soul

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: Fie Polymetes, though the robe of learning, Sit comely on a Prince, yet wean thy thoughts From this strict contemplation, and embrace Public assemblies, knightly exercise.

sp.speaker: Poly.
sp.l: How is that? to swear and give the sudden stab? Sell Lands to purchase fashions? O it is base! Bought gentry, should true born worth disgrace.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.l: Practise to hunt.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.l: No, some that use that sport Give it over, being scarce one hair the better for it.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: Then practise Revels.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.l: Revels sprightly play. Yet every year, some revel all away.

sp.speaker: Lur.
sp.l: All these are trivial: Prince, be a Lawyer:

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.l: Of all Land monsters, some that bear that name, Might well be spared, whose vulture Avarice Devours men living: they of all the rest, Deal most with Angels, and yet prove least blessed.

sp.speaker: Lur.
sp.l: Wrong not the Law.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.l: I cannot, it is divine: And I will compare it to a golden chain, That links the body of a common-wealth, Into a firm and formal Union. It holds the sword, with an impartial hand, Curbs in the rains of an unruly land, It is twined to Justice, and with holy zeal, Rightly determines the poor man's appeal. And those that are laws true administers, Are fathers to the wronged, heaven's Justicers.

sp.speaker: Lur.
sp.l: Fore-god it is true, right properties of the Law But under favour, and with due respect Of that unvalued pearl, and the professors, Yourself and such lack-Latin Advocates Infect the heart, and do their best to change The true intent of sanctimonious law. Turn Churchyards Champions, and make the ground grown rank with Grandsires flesh, Bear corn to feed the Son.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l:
Will this be suffered?
But Polymetes, in thy stay at Pisa, When heardest thou of thy Sister?

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.l: Much too late, The reason, with your patience I will relate. Beauteous Emilia, whom I never saw, But in the Rhetoric of discoursive tongues In Sancta Monta, neighbour to Sardinia, Where silver Arno in her Crystal bosom, Courts the fresh banks with many an amorous kiss. My Sister (as the country custom claimed) With all the choicest virgins of the Land, Met at the Temple half a league remote, From all resort of people,which was decked With all the Relics, and the choicest Gems, Marcellis, Pisa, or Ligorne could yield.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: What followed this rich preparation?

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.l:
Whilst they securely tend their Orisons, Three armed Galleys of the faithless Turkes, At this advantage set their men on shore, Entered the Temple, and profaned their shrines, On the high Altar sacrificed the Priests, Disrayed the Temple of the golden robes, Murdered the matrons, ravished the Maids, And dragging them by the disheveled hair, Did with their ravished bodies fill their boats,
Amongst the rest, Emilia whom report Called by no name but only beautiful, Was ravished, slain, or taken prisoner.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: O Polymetes! thy discourse confounds, Thou healest old hurts, yet givest us deeper wounds, But words are air, see our armed Galleys manned, And in them place as many of our Knights As loved Emilia and their Sovereigns health. I will unto Pisa, and till our return, Because our widowed Dukedom shall not mourn. Be thou her minion, and possess her chair, Fill that with honour, it will fill thee with care, Urge no denials, Genowaes adieu, We leave old griefs, and go in quest of new.

sp.speaker: Lur.
sp.l: Better and better, now my hopes are fit, The Duke thus gone, what tongue so bold dares say I wronged my wife?

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: That dares Horatioes.

sp.speaker: Lur.
sp.l: Thou art myself, we both have but one bosom One tongue, one soul, two bodies and one heart.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: I know it my Lord.

sp.speaker: Lur.
sp.l: It is true, but let that pass, We two are one.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: I know your honour is wise.

sp.speaker: Lur.
sp.l:
And I know thee
For no small fool, two is simple policy, And not without some counsel of the law, That not withstanding my wives near alliance Unto the Duke, I purchased a divorce.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: What was the cause?

sp.speaker: Lur.
sp.l: I tell thee, the most wrong Was this, my Avarice thought she lived too long. I know one man hath coffined up six wives Since she was mine, and by the poorest, pursed A brace of thousand pounds: still good in Law, Men must be rich, by thrift our treasures rise, Give me the man's knave rich, take you poor wise, But close, cock sure I will feed me fat with sport, Gull all, fool all, why? I have Law-tricks for it.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l:
How Justice Slender glories in the plot, Which to deceive him, my full brain begot? But to his wife, true virtue though disgraced, She is now half wooed because she is thought unchaste Her sex's credit, or discredit thrives In the outward shape and fashion of their lives, and be a woman's vertues never so strong, Her honour is weighed upon discourse's tongue. Be her same sullied, were her thoughts as bright As Innocence, the world would count her light. For though amongst women, most are beauteous,
They that please time are counted virtuous, And in this hope, I will to the Countess go, She is counted light, Love grant I find her so.

sp.speaker: Joc.
sp.l: Welcome to Genoa Madam, and to make a short cut of our long travel, faith tell me, how do you feele yourself since you came ashore?

sp.speaker: Em.
sp.l: Feele myself? why with my hands, what an idle question is that?

sp.speaker: Ioc.
sp.l: Then pray be you better occupied in your answer: but Madam, do you remember what a multitude of fishes we saw at Sea? and I do wonder how they can all live by one another.

sp.speaker: Em.
sp.l: Why fool, as men do on the Land, the great ones eat up the little ones, but Ioculo, I am great, passing great, and ready to lie down.

sp.speaker: Joc.
sp.l: Do Madam, and I will stand by and do my good will to deliver you.

sp.speaker: Em.
sp.l: Man's death of what?

sp.speaker: Ioc.
sp.l: Why of your Maiden-head Madam and if you please, or rather of the huge birth of knavery you are in travel of.

sp.speaker: Em.
sp.l: And in sooth Ioculo at this time I stand in some need of a witty Mid-wife: but may I trust thee?

sp.speaker: Ioc.
sp.l:
Above the girdle-stead, and below the knee Madam without any danger, why Madam, you
know at our first meeting in the Turkes Galleys, where we were both prisoners, and in a manner strangers, I rested faithful when we counterfeited ourselves lunatic to escape their fury I proved not false when we were cast naked ashore: I stood firm to you, and never since left your companies now having had these trials of me abroad, never mistrust my secrecy at home.

sp.speaker: Em.
sp.l: I will credit thee, and now receive this embryo of knavery, briefly as I deliver it. I understand since our private arrival here at Genoa, that the Duke my father hearing of my surprisal from Montasancta, attended with a hundred Knights, is gone to seek a needle in a bottle of Hay.

sp.speaker: Io.
sp.l: Or rather to catch a quick Eel by the ---

sp.speaker: Em.
sp.l: Teeth, as I have done you sir?

sp.speaker: Io.
sp.l: Nay, if you break jests in my teeth once, I have done with you.

sp.speaker: Em.
sp.l:
If the breaking of the jest kept your teeth whole, it was well broken: but to the purpose; as well to try what mettle our Genowaies wits are made of, as also to put my Brothers humour to the test, I intend to dance a pretty change with my name (for by nothing else I am sure they can know me, being in my infancy carried to my Aunts at Pisa) then instead of
Emilia, call me Tristella.

sp.speaker: Io.
sp.l: Agreed, but what man in the mist is this?

sp.speaker: Em.
sp.l: I know not yet, let us walk, and take occasion to confer with them.

div2.stage: Enter Polymetes reading, and Iulio taking Tobacco.

sp.speaker: Ioc.
sp.l: Yet keep without eye-shot so long as you can.

sp.speaker: Poly.
sp.l: O most Divine!

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.l: Tobacco? the best in Europe, it cost me ten Crowns an ounce by this vapour.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.l: Art not ashamed?

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.l: Of your foppish humour? yes by this Element villainously ashamed, pox on it, leave it, you are a scholar, go but to antiquity, read the Chronicles, you may find some of your Ancestors chronicled for winning a Wenches favour for loosing their armour, but few for wit and Scholarship: Soldiers and Scholars could never set their horses together, especially in this kicking age: but who comes here? one she-Satyr or other to pitch up her Tent, cast down her gauntlet and proclaim thee coward for not stabbing her, when she gave thee the most plain apparent and open lie.

sp.speaker: Em.
sp.l: Ioculo, we are fallen into their eyes.

sp.speaker: Ioc.
sp.l: They will hardly see their way then, for we are shrewd moats, but all is one, I will give occasion of quarrel, answer it you as you can.

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.l: Your reason Sir?

sp.speaker: Ioc.
sp.l: To make thee recoil, or with the Soldier to fall off, is it your country manner to corrive a leader, being upon or before present service as I am?

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.l: Pardon me sir, I did not see your charge. Would I had never seen her, for her eye Hath set my thoughts in a strange mutiny.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.l: What, in love Iulio?

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.l: No Prince, love is in me, I like a slave endure loves tyranny.

sp.speaker: Ioc.
sp.l: Madam, your Brother.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.l: Slave to all slaves be he that snares his eye, In a weak Sirens Cob-web flattery.

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.l: God save fair sweet.

sp.speaker: Em.
sp.l: Amen, from such as you.

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.l: You had said for such, had your tongue gone true.

sp.speaker: Em.
sp.l: Why then belike I lie.

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.l: I would you did, within my Curtains.

sp.speaker: Em.
sp.l: Marry love forbid.

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.l: Nay, love is willing, for he cries let us go:

sp.speaker: Em.
sp.l: Then love hath two tongues, for he tells me no, so pray let us part.

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.l: What, and our lips not meet?

sp.speaker: Em.
sp.l:
Now fie upon it, like Broom-men in the street? You are a young wooer, or else much too rude,
To show this kindness fore a multitude, But by the blush that colours over your face, You would scarce do it in a more private place.

sp.speaker: Po.
sp.l: This same strange thing in the likeness of a woman, Tastes of much wit, though I not love her sex, I will arm my thoughts to crack a jest with her. What, gravelled Iulio ?

sp.speaker: Em.
sp.l: No, but run a-land: Is your wits shipping any better manned?

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.l: Yes, will you board it?

sp.speaker: Em.
sp.l: No, I dare not venture:

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.l: Make but a shot in jest and you may enter.

sp.speaker: Em.
sp.l: You are a Scholar.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.l: I have seen some Schools.

sp.speaker: Em.
sp.l: You came not over in the last fleet of Fools.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.l: You took my room up.

sp.speaker: Em.
sp.l: I pray take it again, We will have no women fools sail amongst men.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.l: Your wit is much currish.

sp.speaker: Em.
sp.l: Why it bites not you, It feeds on fools flesh, so wise men adieu

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.l: Please you accept the curtsy of the town?

sp.speaker: Em.
sp.l: I need not, I have curtsies of mine own: there is one for you.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.l: How chance your wit is so free?

sp.speaker: Em.
sp.l: Only to outgo Adds company.

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.l: Here are none such.

sp.speaker: Ioc.
sp.l: Take heed, for if you tire, She will keep her pace and leave you in the mire.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.l: A woman's feature, but a Scholars tongue In quick discourse, Philosophers never wondered More at the strange conception of the winds, Than I admire how she attained this wit: Did not true learning make the soul divine, She hath spoke enough to make me convertine.

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.l: My loves are sound, and wait but your reply, A short lined accent, either no or Aye.

sp.speaker: Em.
sp.l: I am not too severe, nor yet so kind, To fall for every idle puff of wind. But farewell, I will take counsel of my pillow, Pity fresh youth should wither in green willow.

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.l: Appoint the place sweet, I will not miss mine hour.

sp.speaker: Em.
sp.l: At the three fools.

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.l: I will meet.

sp.speaker: Em.
sp.l: And make up four.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.l:
Sweet words, kind looks, what? and a parting kiss. Words, looks and lips cry all, the wench is his. I am possessed devil, love persuades my mind, That if to him, to me she will prove more kind.
What is Iulio made of? hadst thou soul or sense, Thou wouldst not prentice thy affections, Nor tie thy fortunes to a strangers love.

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.l: A little liking my Lord, a jerk a trick or so, but no pure love I protest, but be impartial, cast off the furred-gown of hate, and speak out of the naked Doublet and hose of judgment: is she not worthy to be beloved? nay, might not she and I live passing well together?

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.l: Yes, if to live in bondage be no hell, I think you two, might do exceeding well.

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.l: Well my Lord, because I will be no example of self-will, I will break off our meeting at the three Fools, and send for her to Court, where I will put all my love into one quart of Maligo, and your melancholy humour into another, and he that hath done last, shall for penance give her a kick on the lips, and a pipe of Tobacco be my witness, that is all the love I bear her.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.l: Well Iulio, However you juggle, if you do agree, You must be pleased to wear the keepers fee.

sp.speaker: Adam.
sp.l: Sir, I do not love to double with a woman if my friend, much less with you my most upright and straight Count, my young Lord (as I told you) is turned absolute prodigal.

sp.speaker: Lur.
sp.l: How prodigal?

sp.speaker: Adam.
sp.l: Marry thus prodigal, to frequent ordinaries is his ordinary practise, rubs out whole weeks together in bowling. Allies, bandies away his pocket full of french-crowns in a morning, and counts it a pretty sport to procure heat.

sp.speaker: Lur.
sp.l: Thou tellest me wonders, he that but last day, Was never seen to walk without a book, Writ against pleasure, and make bitter jests Of honest recreation, turned dissolute, I see no reason for it, the law and I, (I tell you plainly Adam) think you lie.

sp.speaker: Adam.
sp.l: Think as you will sir, there is not a trick used in the town that deserves damnation, but he desires to deal in it, it is pity he was not made a tradesman, he loves to follow his occupation a life, and that which makes him doubt most, he is in love with the Indian punk Tobacco.

sp.speaker: Lur.
sp.l: Punk! how the fool that doth not know it slanders a leaf, nick-names a stranger herb.

sp.speaker: Adam.
sp.l: No herb a grace I hope sir.

sp.speaker: Lur.
sp.l: Nor good thrift neither, Yet there is one dunce, a kind of plodding Poet, Swears it was not in the first creation, Because he finds no ballad argument, To prove old Adam a Tobacconist.

sp.speaker: Adam.
sp.l: I think none of the name loves it, I have heard old Adam was an honest man, and a good Gardiner loved Lettuce well, Salads and Cabbage reasonable well, yet no Tobacco: Again, Adam Bell a substantial out-law, and passing a good Archer, yet no Tobacconist. Further, Diogenes, whose proper name might be Adam for aught I know, loved Carrots well, Leek porridge passing well, yet no Tobacco: to conclude, my great Grandfathers Grandfathers father, and myself all Gardeners, yet could not abide this Chimney-sweeper Tobacco.

sp.speaker: Lur.
sp.l: They did not: take me with you, what is the cause, They were all plain folks, and did not know the laws.

sp.speaker: Adam.
sp.l: They were plain indeed, and thereof grew the proverb, plain dealing is a Jewel.

sp.speaker: Lur.
sp.l: But he that useth it shall die a beggar.

sp.speaker: Ad.
sp.l: That addition was made by some Lawyer or Poet, to avoid which, they cannot endure plain-dealing should have a hand in any of their actions.

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.l: Touch no man's function, there are irks and tricks Spurn not the law, for if you do, it kicks.

sp.speaker: Ad.
sp.l: So will a spur-galled Jade sir, but to all these misdemeanours, he maintains a private punk, one Tristella that he had in way of reversion from Iulio, a twinger, a mere Horse-leach, one that will suck out the brains of his treasury, and make a mere skin of his wealth, I, out of my Love reprehended his error, and he in a fury kicked me out of doors, and discharged me of his service.

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.l: I like not this, it is neither right nor straight done with no law-trick, nor no good conceit, but here he comes.

sp.speaker: Ad.
sp.l: With Autumn in his bosom, pray God she shake not down his leaves, and leave him to make the Duke his father a bald reckoning.

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.l: Peace and observe.

sp.speaker: Em.
sp.l: Though I be a stranger to you, Yet am I well acquainted with your humour. A Lady cannot live about the Court Without the envy of your Epigrams, If she be pleasant, she is counted light, If ruddy, painted, if her ruffs be thick, They ask much poking.

sp.speaker: Po.
sp.l:
Trust me, love hath killed
That wormwood humour, bring the authority Of one true tongue to prove my poesy, Ever wronged woman.

sp.speaker: Em.
sp.l: And you will do it again?

sp.speaker: Lur.
sp.l: That is a good wench.

sp.speaker: Em.
sp.l: I pray who ought that pen? That in a stammering Iambic vain, Glanced at Emiliaes loose and gaudy train. And broke broad jests upon her narrow heel, Poked her Rebatos, and surveyed her steel, tide her fringed garters, bought her words by weight

sp.speaker: Lur.
sp.l: Still good in law, and an upright conceit.

sp.speaker: Em.
sp.l: Do you not know that man?

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.l: Suppose I do?

sp.speaker: Em.
sp.l: You did but flout them, and you will flout me too You wondered not Cornelia being so fair, Would be beholding to her Laundress hair.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.l: I know not this.

sp.speaker: Em.
sp.l: True, nor that Florymell, Became a Pages habit passing well, Used single Rapier, took the rouse and swore, Of all land Beasts she could not brooke the Bore, Nor that Count Lurdo, coming to a fray, Brought not the worth of one poor hair away.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.l: More than his own.

sp.speaker: Lur.
sp.l: That jest comes near to me, It is outgrown now, it wants authority.

sp.speaker: Em.
sp.l: Nor that Melina whom your Muse renowns Wore out as many suitors as new gowns. And the same day that she was married, Upon her finger wore her maiden-head. In likeness of a Diamond.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.l: Indeed it was said, That for Ring Melina sold her head.

sp.speaker: Em.
sp.l: But you are all Ouids .

sp.speaker: Lur.
sp.l: They are bawdy mates, Touch Lawyers too, indeed abuse all states,

sp.speaker: Em.
sp.l: Poets are wanton, and no doubt enjoy, Their fair Corynnes, though perhaps less coy.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.l: Suppose some do?

sp.speaker: Em.
sp.l: Each one in this agrees to scandal us.

sp.speaker: Lur.
sp.l: And talk of Lawyers fees.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.l: Grant me but love, and with my utmost power, I will defend your sex's stainless honour: And with my pen dipped in the juice of gall, Be his souls terror, that hereafter shall, Cast ink at honours garments, or aspire To name your sex with an unhallowed fire.

sp.speaker: Em.
sp.l: I take your word.

sp.speaker: Poly.
sp.l: Then seal it with a kiss.

sp.speaker: Lur.
sp.l: That kiss my Lord deserves an Epigram.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.l: Sit down good Uncle.

sp.speaker: Lur.
sp.l: An unbidden guest Should bring a stool along.

sp.speaker: Poly.
sp.l: A woman's jest.

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.l: You mean a lie, for women use to lie.

sp.speaker: Em.
sp.l: But not like Scholars by authority.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: Yet they may produce lying authority, and so cannot Poets.

sp.speaker: Lur.
sp.l: Nor Lawyers neither.

sp.speaker: Em.
sp.l: Are you a Lawyer?

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: I'faith Madam, he hath sit on the skirts of law any time this thirty years.

sp.speaker: Ad.
sp.l: Then he should be a good Trencher-man by his profession.

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.l: Your reason Adam .

sp.speaker: Ad.
sp.l: I knew one of that faculty in one term eat up a hole Town, Church, Steeple and all.

sp.speaker: Iu.
sp.l: I wonder the Bells rung not all in his belly.

sp.speaker: Ad.
sp.l: No sir, he sold them to buy his wife a Taffeta Gown, and himself a velvet Jacket.

sp.speaker: Po.
sp.l: What a proved Iacke was that? but I wonder at Lawyers for one thing, many of them use to take their fees afore-hand.

sp.speaker: Em.
sp.l:
For a twofold policy, one is they were commonly
greedy, the other for fear if their Clients follow their Counsel long, they will not be worth a fee.

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.l: It is well said Lady, you do well to jest with an old man.

sp.speaker: Ad.
sp.l: He says true, for if you should jest too much with a young man, it might prove earnest, and so the fruits of your jests make you both ashamed of it.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.l: Well said Adam, but leaving at a full jest, Uncle, what earnest business brought you hither?

sp.speaker: Lur.
sp.l: Your honour's sudden Metamorphosis, Told by your trusty Servant, and confirmed By public rumour.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.l: Why what says Goody Fame, and my trusty Servant

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.l: This is the worst my Lord that you expend Your treasure on that Ladies maintenance.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.l: 'sfoot say I do, what, has the worm-eaten bawd Fame: or ere a pander-like fool else to do with it? give her maintenance, why she is of my near affinity, should I see my she affinity go in tatters? I allow my Servant rags, and I were worse than a Jew, if I should suffer my she affinity to go naked.

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.l:
Law takes your part, and if your purse grow short Rather than spend the public treasury, I will lend your Grace a brace of thousand pounds,
Provided this, that as our Book-men write I have security.

sp.speaker: Em.
sp.l: A Lawyer right?

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.l: Security? Leases and old rents, Castles and Townships, able men, good security, Towns are no Starters, they will hold out wind and weather.

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.l: I crave no more, let me have pawns and use.

sp.speaker: Em.
sp.l: How? Lords turn Usurers? those that should punish brokerage deal upon pawns? If it were once his own, He would lend him money on his Duke-domes crown

sp.speaker: Po.
sp.l: But faith Uncle tell me, what think you of this Lady? would she not make a pretty pert Duchess?

sp.speaker: Lur.
sp.l: She is fair, nor do I discommend your choice I wish her your's, a private friend or so, I know mad Irks, and know that Law allows, Princes their private pleasures, and myself Will do my best to gain your honours love, I will not absolutely say there are, But there may be, if so your honour please, Sellers and Vaults,which from your private Garden May under ground lead to your bed-chamber. Whither, I will not name myself, but some close friend, May unsuspected bring your beauteous Lady.

sp.speaker: Em.
sp.l:
Lord what a broking Advocate is this?
He was some Squires Scrivener, and hath scrapped Gentility out of Attorneys fees: His bastard actions prove him such a one, For true worth scorns to turn Chameleon.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.l: Madam, my Uncle out of tender-love, Better to shun all scandalous suspect, That might attend on our unsuiting loves Will lodge you at his house, whither at turns ---

sp.speaker: Em.
sp.l: Your Grace may have access.

sp.speaker: Lur.
sp.l: It is so indeed.

sp.speaker: Em.
sp.l: Is there a back way?

sp.speaker: Lur.
sp.l: And a private door, A secret vault, and twenty odd tricks more.

sp.speaker: Em.
sp.l: A Stove?

sp.speaker: Lur.
sp.l: And Arbours with sweet violet Beds, That have been pressed to death with maiden-heads, Where you may sport and breath, and take a rouse

sp.speaker: Em.
sp.l: Pardy, this Lawyer keeps a bawdy house, I shall be ready to deceive you all. My Lord, your Law-plot is, most judicial.
But who comes here? some one of your cast clients.

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.l: Godsme, the Countess.

sp.speaker: Lur.
sp.l: Mum, I cannot stay, There is a cloud rising, drives my Sun away.

sp.speaker: Em.
sp.l: Is this your wife?

sp.speaker: Lur.
sp.l: Madam, it is she that was.

sp.speaker: Em.
sp.l: That was and is not? how comes that to pass?

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.l: I cannot tell, God and his conscience knows

sp.speaker: Lur.
sp.l: And the world sees Colossus on my brows, Hercules Pillars, here is non vltra writ.

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.l: Not in brass Characters?

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.l: No, horns more fit.

sp.speaker: Lur.
sp.l: Hath not the Law divorced and made a bar twixt our affections? wert not thou content to take a pension?

sp.speaker: Coun.
sp.l: Which you still detain.

sp.speaker: Lur.
sp.l: Good wit, Law-tricks and firm, you may complain.

sp.speaker: Cou.
sp.l: Complain I do, I kneel before the throne and sue for Justice, but yet can purchase none. Complain I do Cousin.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.l: Away.

sp.speaker: Cou.
sp.l: O, as you are a Prince, and you a virgin.

sp.speaker: Em.
sp.l: I was one long since, This is no place for passion, dry your eyes,

sp.speaker: Cou.
sp.l: Grief nails me to the ground, I cannot rise, I will grow immodest, justice is exiled, And so shall duty, patience turn wild,

sp.speaker: Po.
sp.l: Come, leave the Bedlam.

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.l: Do, for wit and Law know she is a fool,

sp.speaker: Em.
sp.l: A couple quoth Jackdaw.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: Madam.

sp.speaker: Co.
sp.l: Who calls?

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: Madam.

sp.speaker: Co.
sp.l: Horatio.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: In passion Lady.

sp.speaker: Co.
sp.l: Discontent or so.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: Be not, be counselled, do not let despair, Like the rank canker bred by sultry air. Eat this young Rose of beauty in the bud: But in the April Sun of youthful blood Let the sweet blossom ripen, thrive and grow, To those full joyswhich none but Lovers know.

sp.speaker: Co.
sp.l: The man talks idly, tell me I am fair, Lovely and young.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l:
You are, by love you are, Not fair, you are: Leanders paramour: Compared with you was a swarthy Blackamoor Your hair is softer than the Colchean Fleece, Your well limbed features, natures master piece Your eyes two Diamonds, set in purer mould Than rocks of coral, or the Indian gold. In thy smooth chin there is an Ivory pit, Where blushing Uenus and young Cupid sit, Feathering of golden shafts, the wounding heads,
Made of thy amber-tresses finest threads.

sp.speaker: Co.
sp.l: You will not buy me sure you praise me so.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: Yet fair, I will bid fair for you ere I go,

sp.speaker: Co.
sp.l: He that bids fair for me deceives his eye.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: By heaven he doth not.

sp.speaker: Co.
sp.l: Wilful perjury, what means all this?

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: This my discourse intends, Were husbands Saints, some wives would have close friends.

sp.speaker: Co.
sp.l: Some bad perhaps, but ---

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: Husbands but for it, true, wilt? prithee wilt thou?

sp.speaker: Co.
sp.l: What?

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: Ud's Heartlings do?

sp.speaker: Co.
sp.l: Do what?

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: Love-tricks quickly, wilt thou prithee.

sp.speaker: Cou.
sp.l: No, I prize my credit.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: Credit? life-a-man, What talks of credit? art not known a strumpet?

sp.speaker: Cou.
sp.l: You do me wrong.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l:
Damnation, what a gloss, This gilded copper, Diamond of glass, What strange show it makes? I will give you a colour Your face was never worse painted, than I will paint Your Wain-scot credit, you are a private bit,
Kept for some great made Diues. Red hot scandal Suck the native colour of your souls As it hath scorched thy credit, shrivelled Bawd, Sponge, Lemon-pill, and more irrelishable Than over-dried Stock-fish, fie.

sp.speaker: Co.
sp.l: Upon thy shame.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: Thy husband, O thy husbands bowlegged fame Death I shall hate thee.

sp.speaker: Co.
sp.l: O for honour do.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: Swear thou art my strumpet.

sp.speaker: Co.
sp.l: I will endure that too.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: Shalt not deny it, heart, canst not.

sp.speaker: Cou.
sp.l: Yes, I can.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: Do it for thy life, thy soul, base courtesan.

sp.speaker: Co.
sp.l: Farewell, if friendship be at such a rate, Before I will purchased, I will live still in hate.

sp.speaker: Pa.
sp.l: Heart, a new fashion, A Lady poor, beautiful and chaste? clean From the bias of Custom: to be poor, painted, And proud is as common in Genoa, as felt and feather In the fortunate Island: but chaste and poor, As singular and rare, as Conscience with the Anabaptist.

sp.speaker: Cou.
sp.l: Come hither Boy, didst never owe me service

sp.speaker: Pag.
sp.l: Yes Madam, more than ever I paid you honestly, and were he not my Master.

sp.speaker: Cou.
sp.l: Thy Master, who?

sp.speaker: Pa.
sp.l: Horatio, he that puts chastity to the quick, and honour to the stab, but I will show him the nature of a right French-man, deny him homage, forswear allegiance, and come behind hand in cash keeping, and with his own purse maintain you against him.

sp.speaker: Cou.
sp.l: Thy purpose briefly.

sp.speaker: Pa.
sp.l: In bald sentences, your noted wrongs are pitied.

sp.speaker: Cou.
sp.l: Pitied, by whom?

sp.speaker: Pa.
sp.l: By me, lodgings prepared and diet,which I humbly tender your honour, as first payment of the ancient debt, my service owes you.

sp.speaker: Cou.
sp.l: But is the lodging private?

sp.speaker: Pa.
sp.l: At mine own mothers, and though I say it, she keeps an honest house, though my father be a Citizen.

sp.speaker: Cou.
sp.l: Of what profession?

sp.speaker: Pa.
sp.l: Neither her fool nor Physician, but an ingenious Apothecary.

sp.speaker: Cou.
sp.l: And what resort?

sp.speaker: Pag.
sp.l: Very civil and most quiet resort, patients, the house is set round with patients twice or thrice a day, and because they will be sure not to want drink, everyone brings his own water in an Urinal with him.

sp.speaker: Cou.
sp.l: Doth he use physic too? that is beyond his warrant.

sp.speaker: Pa.
sp.l: O Lord Madam, better men than he strain courtesy with their warrants in this age, besides, you being musical, shall meet much content, for my mother lodges three or four Knights and Ladies Daughters that practise music and needle-work, and will no doubt be exceeding proud of your company, will it please you walk?

sp.speaker: Co.
sp.l: Thou art the Star, by whom my fate is led, My shame is so public, I would fain hide my head.

div2.head: Actus Tertius.

sp.speaker: Lur.
sp.l: Currant in Law, and how encountered you.

sp.speaker: Win.
sp.l: I will tell you my good Lord (I thank my bringing up, I can talk, I use not to have my tongue to seek when it should pleasure any man, especially my good Lord) I told her what a credit it was to have a man of great credit, and thatwhich is more, a skilful Lawyer that can stand out in her case at a dead lift, and one that if need were, could make a crazy action sound, I put her in mind what it was to have such a one to her sweet heart.

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.l: Thou speakest but right, for so I am indeed.

sp.speaker: Wi.
sp.l: You are, I urged it, and she confessed to me that the very first night she saw you she dreamed on you, and wished you in her bed, and her bed in the midst of the River.

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.l: How, in the the River?

sp.speaker: Win.
sp.l: Yes forsooth,

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.l: In the middle of the tide.

sp.speaker: Win.
sp.l: Yes in her dream.

sp.speaker: Lur.
sp.l: Good, But she doth love me.

sp.speaker: Win.
sp.l:
Believe it my Lord she doth, marry you must think I drew her and drew her, and wrought her and wrought her, till I made her as pliant and, tractable
as wax, marry with all, she is as constant as Lucretia, and will not for a thousand pounds, till she hath the law of her side.

sp.speaker: Lur.
sp.l: I sound her meaning, first I will gull my Nephew.

sp.speaker: Win.
sp.l: Her intent right, she intends to make a Gull of the Prince, and an absolute Goose of you.

sp.speaker: Lur.
sp.l: Still good in Law, I will fetch him over of all, Get all, purse all, and be possessed of all, And then conclude the match, marry at least, When can you tell? I will use her as a hand To pick the Princes coffers, and for reward To prison, marry her, for tricks can do it, The world is squint-eyed, and dares not pry into our actions. Here lies her walk (my Lute Win) she shall see, Youth is leaden footed in respect of me.

sp.speaker: Em.
sp.l: Win, prithee give the Fiddler a testar and send him packing, what a scraping the rogue keeps? does he think the Count keeps a Tavern or a Bawdy-house? my good Lord! beseech your honour pardon me.

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.l: No harm sweet Love, how dost thou like this Caper?

sp.speaker: Em.
sp.l: Passing well my Lord, will you never leave these coltish tricks? but to the matter: I sent you my resolution by your Maid, have you received it.

sp.speaker: Lur.
sp.l: I have, and it holds currant, Then tender me possession.

sp.speaker: Em.
sp.l: Of what?

sp.speaker: Lur.
sp.l: Of thy chaste love.

sp.speaker: Em.
sp.l: Not too much haste for that, you have a wife.

sp.speaker: Lur.
sp.l: I had one.

sp.speaker: Em.
sp.l: And still have.

sp.speaker: Lur.
sp.l: Thy love shall quickly wed her to her grave, I never did love her.

sp.speaker: Em.
sp.l: When she was a maid You swore you did, how soon poor youth is betrayed To helpless ruin: do you love me?

sp.speaker: Lur.
sp.l: Aye faith.

sp.speaker: Em.
sp.l: For how long?

sp.speaker: Lur.
sp.l: Till death.

sp.speaker: Em.
sp.l:
O deadly lie. I will tell you just how long, love is bred in the blood, Prospers as long as beauties in the bud. When beauty withers, lustful love grows cold, And ere it be half ripe, it is rotten old. If you have me, you must not put on yellows, I will have myself, my servant and my fellows. My love, my liking, and a second me, I love to relish sweet variety: Your old wife moved you, I shall vex you more.
Take Coach with Gallants even afore your door. Take Rings, give bracelets woven of my hair, Which to spite you, my Servants arm shall wear. I will in your presence sit upon his knee, Exchanging kisses if you speak to me. I will pout in scorn, cry mew, and look aside, At which, if you but frown, I will roundly chide, I am not as I seem, dissembling wit Is my best means.

sp.speaker: Lur.
sp.l: Square to my humour fit.

sp.speaker: Em.
sp.l: I was a Beggar born.

sp.speaker: Lur.
sp.l: And so was I.

sp.speaker: Em.
sp.l: Traded in lust and gainful brothelry.

sp.speaker: Lur.
sp.l:
The fitter for my turn, I was a man Born to no hopes, but a few shreds of wit A Grammar Scholar, then a Scrivener. Dealing for private use betwixt man and man, and by close brokerage set them at debate: Incensed them unto Law,which to maintain, I lent them money upon Lands and Plate, After the rate of seven-score in the hundred. Then did I learn to counterfeit men's hands, Noblemen's arms, interline Evidences, Make false conveyances, yet with a trick, Close and cock-sure, I cony-catched the world.
Having scraped pretty wealth, I fell in League With my first wife, and (though I say it myself) She had good doings, her back comings in And private goings out, raised me aloft: I followed cases of the law abroad, and she was merry with her friends at home.

sp.speaker: Em.
sp.l: Did you never take her kissing?

sp.speaker: Lur.
sp.l: Twenty times.

sp.speaker: Em.
sp.l: Were you not Jealous?

sp.speaker: Lur.
sp.l: Never nothing less.

sp.speaker: Em.
sp.l: Yet saw her kiss with Strangers.

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.l: Kiss and play.

sp.speaker: Em.
sp.l: And were you a Cuckold.

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.l: Cuckold by this light.

sp.speaker: Em.
sp.l: What? a wittol.

sp.speaker: Lur.
sp.l: And a Wittol too.

sp.speaker: Em.
sp.l: And knew it?

sp.speaker: Lur.
sp.l: And knew it.

sp.speaker: Em.
sp.l: And suffered it.

sp.speaker: Lur.
sp.l: I did.

sp.speaker: Lur.
sp.l: It went attired in gold, a golden Crest, Is a brave fashion, and accounted best.

sp.speaker: Wen.
sp.l: Madam, my Lord.

sp.speaker: Lur.
sp.l: What news?

sp.speaker: Win.
sp.l: The Prince.

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.l: The Prince.

sp.speaker: Win.
sp.l: And Iulio.

sp.speaker: Lur.
sp.l: Which way?

sp.speaker: Em.
sp.l: Where?

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.l: From thence.

sp.speaker: Win.
sp.l: That way the vault, from thence the private door, as I stood Sentinel at the further end of the Vault, they being unacquainted with the turnings, came groping and feeling, as commonly men will do especially in a strange place, and as I am true sinner, had I not spied the Diamond on his finger (twin, to this on my conscience) they had been upon me in the dark ere I had been aware of them.

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.l: The Prince.

sp.speaker: Win.
sp.l: And Iulio.

sp.speaker: Em.
sp.l: Quick away.

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.l: What plot?

sp.speaker: Em.
sp.l: Behind the Arras? scaped behind the Arras.

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.l: Behind the Arras.

sp.speaker: Em.
sp.l: Close, cock, sure, be wise, They only thrive that best can temporise.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.l: A rare vault by this light, and never devised without the advice of a grand Jury of Bawds, a word with your lips Tris.

sp.speaker: Win.
sp.l: As god mend me Prince you smell bawdy.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.l: Since I came into thy company Win. And how is it Tris? fore-God a pretty lodging.

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.l: And very fair hangings.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.l: Passing good workman-ship, what story is this Tris?

sp.speaker: Em.
sp.l: Why my Lord? the Poetical fiction of Venus kissing Adonis in the violet bed.

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.l: Fore-god it is true, and mark where the Cuckoldly knave Vulcan stands sneaking behind the brake bush to watch them.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.l: A pretty conceit Iulio, dost see Vulcan with the horning parenthesis in his fore-head! I hit indirectly upon the least pap at three passes for a hundred Crowns.

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.l: Not for a hundred.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.l: Is it a match?

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.l: It is done, where will you take your stand?

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.l: Here, anywhere, heart has the Arras an ague, it trembles so?

sp.speaker: Em.
sp.l: No, Vulcan is fearful.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.l: And with a fear it comes, have at the Cuckold.

sp.speaker: Lur.
sp.l: O!

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.l: Hark, the Arras is in labour.

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.l: Mass I heard something groan.

sp.speaker: Poly.
sp.l: I will be the Mid-wife and help to deliver it.

sp.speaker: Em.
sp.l: Sweet Prince.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.l: Hark Wench, I smell Bores grease.

sp.speaker: Em.
sp.l: Will you but hear me?

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.l: Now excuse what trick?

sp.speaker: Em.
sp.l: How? but a Picture? I will try that presently, If you love me, disfigure it not, I esteem it only for the lively workmanship.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.l: Then let me have a sight on it.

sp.speaker: Em.
sp.l: Upon condition you will neither deface it with weapon, nor soil it with your breath ---

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.l: On my Virginities maiden-head we will not discover Lurdo behind the Arras.

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.l: Hart-a-the-Devil, your Uncle.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.l: O forbear, foreGod passing good workman indeed.

sp.speaker: Em.
sp.l: Mark but the glance of his eye.

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.l: The hanging of his neither lip.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.l: The blush of his cheek.

sp.speaker: Win.
sp.l: The curl of his hair.

sp.speaker: Em.
sp.l: The pit of a chin.

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.l: What a smooth hand he hath?

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.l: Long fingers like a Lady.

sp.speaker: Win.
sp.l: Not so much but a seal Ring.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.l: Arms and all, viz a tame Gudgeon.

sp.speaker: Em.
sp.l:
And the fool swallows it rarely, if you mark
him.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.l: Is the numb Ass insensible of Scoffs? I will touch him nearer, yet mine eye deceives me, And this be not Count Lurdoes counterfeit.

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.l: You may soon know that my Lord.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.l: As How?

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.l: If it be his, he hath the Gout in his left foot,

sp.speaker: Poll,
sp.l: The very same, his shoe is cut and all, Farewell Tris, and yet I will startle him a little better before we leave him, fore-god it is so like him, I doubt, whether it be the shadow or his substance.

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.l: A block.

sp.speaker: Em.
sp.l: A shadow.

sp.speaker: Win.
sp.l: A mere senseless stone.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.l: Then it is a counterfeit.

sp.speaker: Em.
sp.l: An absolute counterfeit, what do you mean?

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.l: Marry many Counterfeits walk in the likeness of good money, and so may this do, which to prevent I will nail him to a post, for fear he pass currant on your lips in my absence, and so deceive me?

sp.speaker: Em.
sp.l: I will swear he shall not, gentle Prince be short, Length kills the heart of the most feeling sport.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.l:
Well Maiden, I am content, this jest shall reprieve your head for this once, but beware the next encounter,
come Ariadnes clew, will you unwind, and light us through this vault of darkness, and there is your Naulum.

sp.speaker: Win.
sp.l: Thank you my Lord, if your business stand this way at midnight, I will let you in by this token, and take this from me, when you come again, bring the Lady a Diamond, or some pretty and foolish stone, for I can tell you these same paltry stones are in high request amongst Ladies, especially such old mousers as I have been in my time, and as I say when you come, be not ashamed to knock, and if I come not knock lustily, and again, and never give over knocking till you hear my hem, did you never know Wins hem?

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.l: Never.

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.l: Why hast thou a private hem?

sp.speaker: Win.
sp.l: Have I? I'faith sir aye, few Gallants in the town that are of any standing at all, but are acquainted with my hem, but come close my Lord, close, and be sure the next time you come you do not forget to knock lustily,

sp.speaker: Em.
sp.l: My Lord.

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.l: My Love, my life, O thou art made Out of the soul of wit, and thy conceits, Of the best fashion.

sp.speaker: Em.
sp.l: Did you taste the jest?

sp.speaker: Lu:
sp.l:
Divinely, O divinely, tart and quick,
Pleasing, yet not tedious I was wrapped

sp.speaker: Em.
sp.l: In a knaves skin.

sp.speaker: Lur.
sp.l: My senses were entranced.

sp.speaker: Em.
sp.l: Into a fools Paradise.

sp.speaker: Lur.
sp.l: O my sweet Phoenix, out of thy ashes.

sp.speaker: Em.
sp.l: Is your love so hot, you mean to burn me?

sp.speaker: Lur.
sp.l: O! it honeyed me, And then their numbness, didst thou never read Of any Lawyer came to be Duke?

sp.speaker: Em.
sp.l: Never, but I have heard of a Cuckold that was an Usurper.

sp.speaker: Lur.
sp.l: Why such a one would I be.

sp.speaker: Em.
sp.l: What, a Cuckold?

sp.speaker: Lur.
sp.l: Yes, and an Usurper too.

sp.speaker: Em.
sp.l: So you are, for you Lawyers usurp more crowns than half a Country.

sp.speaker: Lur.
sp.l: Vlisses, Tully, Lawyers, but no Dukes.

sp.speaker: Em.
sp.l: Menelaus and Vulcan were Cuckolds but no Lawyers.

sp.speaker: Lur.
sp.l: Before me it is true, but now I do remember naught to that purpose:

sp.speaker: Em.
sp.l: The most lustful Goats Wear gilded horns, and go in Velvet Coats.

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.l: What news Win?

sp.speaker: Win.
sp.l:
Faith ordinary household news, yonder is a well-faced
Gentleman craves he may change a word with you.

sp.speaker: Lur.
sp.l: His name?

sp.speaker: Win.
sp.l: Horatio.

sp.speaker: Lur.
sp.l: Leave us to confer.
A trusty friend is, the souls high Treasurer.
In dumps Horatio? what, my second self clouded with passion?

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: O my honoured Lord, Our souls and our affections are made all of one fashion now the slightest wrong that scars the reputation of my friend, stabs daggers to my heart.

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.l: I know it true, and I can prove it, Our loves are twins, But to the wrong, dares any idle tongue Bark at our greatness?

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: Yes.

sp.speaker: Lur.
sp.l: Their names?

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: Your wife.

sp.speaker: Lur.
sp.l: My wife? the manner?

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: Amongst her lustful Mates, She shames not to give out, that by your greatness, knowledge, credit, and friends in highest place, You have divorced her without due desert.

sp.speaker: Lur.
sp.l:
We must demur of this, I will have a trick
By way of Habeas Corpus to remove This talking Gossip, come Horatio, Some project, how? what course for her remove:

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: I cannot counsel, but fore-god my Lord, My lodgings mightily annoyed with rats, That eat my papers and deface my books How should I rid them.

sp.speaker: Lur.
sp.l: Easily, poison them, And well remembered, this she Rat my wife, That eats and tears the leaves of my repute, Shall taste like speeding Physic in thine ear, Canst temper poison?

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: Yes.

sp.speaker: Lur.
sp.l: And kill a Rat.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: That she shall never swell on it.

sp.speaker: Lur.
sp.l: Mum for that, This she Rat is a Devil.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: A Limb of Satan.

sp.speaker: Lur.
sp.l: Envy.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: Destruction.

sp.speaker: Lur.
sp.l: Malice.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: Ratsbane do it?

sp.speaker: Lur.
sp.l: Ere my disgrace get age, rare tricks and I Will fool the world, wilt do it?

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: The Rat shall die.

div2.stage: Enter Countesse, three or foure young Gentlewomen, sowing by an houre-glasse.

sp.speaker: Cou.
sp.l: Quick pretty Damsels, that your task were done The fore-noons eldest minute is almost run.

sp.speaker: 1 Gen.
sp.l: Then the glass runs too fast.

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.l: I think not so, Hadst thou my cares, thou wouldst think it ran too slow.

sp.speaker: 2 Gen.
sp.l: I have my task forsooth.

sp.speaker: Co.
sp.l: So have not I. Yet with these sands my sorrows run away I turn them with the glass, the glass is run, Yet my huge mass of cares is scarce begun, Here is a fault, little one what work make you.

sp.speaker: 1 Gen.
sp.l: True stitch forsooth.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.l: Then see you work it true.

sp.speaker: 3 Gent.
sp.l: Pray madam teach me to take out this knot Of heart's ease.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.l: Heart's ease, I have almost forgot, I could have wrought it well when I was young: But in good sadness, I have had none long. What is that?

sp.speaker: 2 Gent.
sp.l: A branch of Rue.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.l: A common weed, of all herbs else I work that well indeed, how chance your flower is behind the glass?

sp.speaker: 2 Gen.
sp.l: Indeed I will get it up:

sp.speaker: Coun.
sp.l:
Indeed alas.
I cannot chide with her, yet tyrant care, At my entreat will not one sight forbear:

sp.speaker: 2 Gen.
sp.l: Why sigh you madam?

sp.speaker: Cou.
sp.l: O I grieve to see, Youth run to cath at their own misery. You are like April or Rose buds in May, You never wither, till the wedding day, Even so did I, so pretty souls will you, Youth wears mild Heart's ease, marriage bitter Rue.

sp.speaker: 2 Gen.
sp.l: Be not so sad, good madam, do but smile, We will have a song sad sorrow to beguile.

sp.speaker: Her.
sp.l: Save you fair Ladies, madam, my business leads me to you.

sp.speaker: Coun.
sp.l: If in your ancient suite, My ears are deafened and my utterance mute.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: Your ear, be wood, what should beget this coins Were I a stranger, or some City Gull I would commend thee, but I know the world. Lodging is costly, maintenance asks charge: Thou art divorced and hast no other help, But thy bare comings in: accept my Love, I will allow thee twenty pound a quarter. To buy thee Pins.

sp.speaker: Count
sp.l: Leave this immodest suite. Or by my honour ---

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: Come, these words of course My fame, mine honour, and my dear respect: Are but like Ignes fatui to delude, Green and unseasoned wits, pry thee be kind, A gilded slip carries as fair a show, As perfect gold, guilt honour may do so

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.l: But put your slip to trial, the slight gold, Is soon rubbed off:

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: Come, thy distinctions sold Let not thy April beauty like a Rose, Fade in the bud, and ripened pleasures lose, My sword thy honour: thy estate my purse, Shall man and strengthen,

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.l: I detest that course.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: Your husband hath a sweet heart:

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.l: For his ill. Shall I turn traitor and mine own fame kill?

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: It is dead already, every idle tongue, Stabs it to death.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.l: I have the greater wrong.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: Thou wrongest thyself and spurnest thy proper good Am I not youthful see my wanton blood Danceth within my veins, and blushing, Courts Thy generous beauty to more amorous sports, You shall not choose.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.l: hands off.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: I love thee dear.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.l: I hate thee deadly.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: Dost thou?

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.l: Shall I swear?

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: No, I will believe thee Phoenix of thy sex, I glory in thy vertues, and reveal, What by my oath I promised to conceal. Your jealous husband urged me to this trial, Pawning his oath upon your strict denial, all bastard Jealousy should be exiled, and ancient love entirely reconciled. I touched your heart, and now I find it true, I will give you notice, I will empoison you.

sp.speaker: Co.
sp.l: Thou speakest all comfort.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: I was made of hope. and rich performance waits upon my words.

sp.speaker: Cou.
sp.l: Father of my fair fortunes, whose rich love begets this reuniting covenant, When comes this long expected sealing day?

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: Tomorrow, the hour eight.

sp.speaker: Cou.
sp.l: Certain?

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: As life.

sp.speaker: Cou.
sp.l: Then follow me to feast, Thy news Horatio is the Welcomest guest.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: Swell heart, hold bosom, yield not to relent, and yet her beauty, colourable trash, Her vertues, vengeance Hypocritical, I love her, fury, poison, Hidraes gall, Impatience man me, black damnation Usher my practice, poison play thy part, and do my latest greetings to her heart. We all must down, yet here the difference lies. Many for sins, she for her virtue dies.

div2.head: Actus Quartus.
div2.stage: Enter Polymetes Julio, Horatio, Emilia & Pages

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.l: Ttristella.

sp.speaker: Em.
sp.l: My Lord?

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.l: Good wine needs no bush, nor a good face painting thou art favour of thyself, and what thou cost is not under a colour.

sp.speaker: Em.
sp.l: I know no other painter but one, and her name is modesty, and she sometimes throws a blush into my face to make my pale cheeks red, but else you shall never take me for an Alderman's post.

sp.speaker: Po.
sp.l: Why an Alderman's post?

sp.speaker: Em.
sp.l: Mark but where great posts are newly painted, you shall see much egress and regress in and out, and where you see a face newly ochred, it is a sign there is great traffic, and much stirring to and fro.

sp.speaker: Po.
sp.l: Come sit, sit, nay nearer, nearer, nearer yet.

sp.speaker: Em.
sp.l: Then I shall sit upon your skirts.

sp.speaker: Po.
sp.l: Iulio and Horatio, what shall us have to supper? I am now in the spending vain.

sp.speaker: Em.
sp.l: Then God for me: what make I so near?

sp.speaker: Po.
sp.l:
Good action, you shall not remove, I learnt that phrase of mine uncle, boy, know what Adam hath bespoken for our palates. Where there a banquet to be had, More rare and dear, than that Vitellius made:
It should be served in, but Horatio, What shall we eat that is costly, and that is rare?

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: A roasted Phoenix were excellent good for that Lady.

sp.speaker: Em.
sp.l: And why for that Lady.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: Far fetched and dear bought, is good for you know who.

sp.speaker: Em.
sp.l: For Ladies.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: Aye for Ladies.

sp.speaker: Em.
sp.l: Then the most cheap stuff, and next to hand is good for you know who.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: For knaves.

sp.speaker: Em.
sp.l: Aye for knaves.

sp.speaker: Iu.
sp.l: Adam what have you ready.

sp.speaker: Ad.
sp.l: Sir you may have a Calveshead.

sp.speaker: Em.
sp.l: Here is a Gentleman hath one in his hat already, no more. Calves head I pray thee.

sp.speaker: Po.
sp.l: Hast any Pheasants or Partridges?

sp.speaker: Ad.
sp.l: No, but if your Lord-ship will have a dish of Woodcocks.

sp.speaker: Em.
sp.l: No for God-sake, they are the stalest meat with me of any, for I never sit to meat with these gallants, but there is Woodcocks clean through the table.

sp.speaker: Ad.
sp.l:
Then unless you will have a Dotterel or a
Gull.

sp.speaker: Em.
sp.l: A Gull? whywhich of these Gent. would thou serve in? do you not hear how Adam flouts you?

sp.speaker: Ad.
sp.l: I mean a Sea-gull baked.

sp.speaker: Em.
sp.l: Aye in any case let us have that, I have fed my wit on many a land-Gull, once let me banquet myself of a Sea-gull, some Sea Captain, I lay my life that has a desire to sup with me, but such as thou hast, I prithee be brief

sp.speaker: Po.
sp.l: Lay the table in the with-drawing room.

sp.speaker: Ad.
sp.l: I will sir, your honour can have no Larks I will assure you.

sp.speaker: Poll,
sp.l: And why?

sp.speaker: Ad.
sp.l: Two Citizens sons and a Poet bought up all in the town, flung away the bodies only to have a pie made of the brains.

sp.speaker: Emi.
sp.l: A sign either they lacked brains, or else they did it because they would bear a brain.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: It was told me that the young Lord Polymetes Was entered here.

sp.speaker: Po.
sp.l: He that so told thee fellow told thee true.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: I cry your Lordship mercy, let this letter Supply the unwilling office of my tongue, And be the sad reporter of my news.

sp.speaker: Poll,
sp.l:
What ominous news can Polimetes daunt?
Have we not Hyren here?

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: Ouid not all thy Metamorphosis Can show such transformation, O my God! It is not possible, (is this my son?) He has mistook himself, my life he has, For the seven liberal sciences; he reads, The seven black deadly sins. Must you needs son turn over these linen leaves having such store of paper? this is miraculous.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.l: News, news my hearts will make your jocund souls dance in your bosoms, nowwhich joyful tongue amongst you all cries first God save the Duke? God save Duke Polymetes.

sp.speaker: Iu.
sp.l: The news is not so happy.

sp.speaker: Po.
sp.l: Tush look here.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: My Lord I am sorry for your heaviness.

sp.speaker: Po.
sp.l: Thou shouldst have said so to a Porter that is heavy laden. But come, sit, sit in council, let us devise How to spend all this countless mass of wealth, My father hath bequeathed me at his death, Quite from the popular and vulgar garb, We will be ode in all things, and retain No common humour in our large expense.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l:
An honourable mind, and were your father
Alive to note these hopeful parts in you, How would it move him and surprise his heart? But now my lord: my message being done, I must return I am glad I have found your son.

sp.speaker: Po.
sp.l: For thy good news take that along with thee,
Look here Tris, would not these Make notable states-men? methinks state steals upon me.

sp.speaker: Em.
sp.l: And I have known some steal state.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.l: Then they came never truly by it as I do, but pergite porro, methinks I could make an indifferent careless Duke.

sp.speaker: Iu.
sp.l: And I could make a notable Courtier, methinks I am begging already.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.l: O mine Uncle would make an Excellent Court spaniel, he would sent out offices and concealed lands, a hundred mile off, and he were my cashier but twenty years, I durst change livings with him.

sp.speaker: Emi.
sp.l: But what employment for Horatio?

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.l: O, he would make a good grumbling surly politician, thou shalt be my politician.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: I shall never be loved.

sp.speaker: Iu.
sp.l: Not loved, your reason?

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.l:
I hate the base and rascal multitude, I cannot nod, ride bare-head through the streets, Nor wreath my body like a Cable Hat-band
To every Peddler and mechanic Townsman, I hate the poor, am envious at the rich, Love none.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.l: Yes, women.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: Faith after a sort, I love a good smooth face.

sp.speaker: Em.
sp.l: Then you love mine.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: And forty more.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.l: I muse you do not marry.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: I would tonight, upon condition That I might bury her tomorrow, God Boy.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.l: Fill him some wine.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: I cannot drink, god boy.

sp.speaker: Po.
sp.l: It is not poisoned.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: Hum, I cannot tell, The Countess drunk and died.

sp.speaker: Po.
sp.l: Come, come.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: Farewell.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.l:
Still in the bogs of Melancholy, pax on it, it is staler than Tobacco, not so much but the singing Cobbler is grown melancholy, and corrects shoes in humour, fie on it, come sit, we must talk about many matters, Riuo, I will be singular, my Royal expense shall run such a circular course that the Rascal spawn of Imitators shall split their wooden brains, and sink their wealth in the Gulf of prodigality, and yet like a
bad Archers shaft, fall six score short of their aim, my expense shall be royal and peculiar.

sp.speaker: Em.
sp.l: I will fashion you a course.

sp.speaker: Po.
sp.l: Divinely, come.

sp.speaker: Em.
sp.l: Divinely indeed, serve God, live honestly relish not Atheism.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.l: That is clean out of the fashion indeed.

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.l: Then good.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.l: Because out of the fashion, set down that Adam

sp.speaker: Ad.
sp.l: It is done.

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.l: I have it my Lord, I have it i'faith.

sp.speaker: Po.
sp.l: Nay quickly, how?

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.l: We will keep no Pages.

sp.speaker: Po.
sp.l: Excellent, that is clean out of the fashion for Pages, that is good, that stands, down with it Adam.

sp.speaker: Ad.
sp.l: It is done sir.

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.l: We will use no great Horses.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.l: How shall we ride then?

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: On Mules and she Asses.

sp.speaker: Em.
sp.l: Down with that Adam.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.l: But, for my train, for a Page with Pages.

sp.speaker: Em.
sp.l:
Maintain a hundred Gallants at your heels, Live in the Country, entertain again Into the Court, long-banished hospitality, Who since the first great hose with Codpieces grew
out of fashion never durst show his head.

sp.speaker: Po.
sp.l: Another, set it down, I will spend after forty pound a day, I will seewhich of my cheverel brained imitators dares follow my fashion: 'sblood I cannot drink Tobacco two days, but the third the Churchwardens and sidemen are at it in the Alehouse in sermon time, I cannot wear a suit half a day but the Tailors Journeyman creeps into it: I cannot keep a block private, but every Citizens son thrusts his head into it: I cannot keep a wench but every grand-Juror's son in the Country imitates me, I care not if I make it petty treason for any man to kiss under ten pound a Kiss.

sp.speaker: Ad.
sp.l: O my Lord, it will never pass in the the Lowerhouse, they will not lose their liberty of kissing.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: Then keep a leash of Wenches.

sp.speaker: Po.
sp.l: As common as cracking of nuts, not a serving-man, but doth as much.

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.l: Fore-god I have it, peculiar I have it.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.l: What is it Iulio?

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.l: Your honour shall keep no wenches at all.

sp.speaker: Em.
sp.l: No wenches? what shall become of me then?

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.l: I must be round with you Tris, you must pack, many women they say are common, and I will entertain nothing that savours of Community, I will not divulge.

sp.speaker: Em.
sp.l:
Nay, but hark you my Lord, though you maintain
me, you do not lie with me, and I think that is the newer fashion.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.l: Fore-god the newest of all, for there is not a gallant maintains his wench but he will lie with her, down with that Adam.

sp.speaker: Ad.
sp.l: It is done.

sp.speaker: Ioc.
sp.l: My Lord my Lord, the Duke your father with a great train is coming.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.l: From heaven or hell.

sp.speaker: Ioc.
sp.l: That is more than I know, but by the faith of a page, or the word of a Gent.which you will, he is arrived and in great state entered the City.

sp.speaker: Iu.
sp.l: Zounds where is the slave that brought the false report of his death?

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.l: But art sure it is my father?

sp.speaker: Ioc.
sp.l: Or else your Mother did you the more wrong, shift for yourselves, for he is come.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.l: My father alive and come home, heart-a-me what shift? come home and find the Court turned Ale-house Dicing-house, Dancing school, I am undone horse and foot.

sp.speaker: Em.
sp.l: Some Rosasolis or Aqua mirabilis ho, for our general coward is in a swoon.

sp.speaker: Po.
sp.l:
I know you are a hot shot in a feather-bed Tris, but that will not serve turn now, therefore fall off, the
enemy is too strong, deed Tris, every Lamb to his fold, and Cony to her Borough, for the old Fox is abroad no, wilt not be? why then God-a-mercyes brain. Cedant arma togæ, my gown and books boy, some sudden devise to keep him back half an hour, and win my good opinion forever.

sp.speaker: Ioc.
sp.l: If I do not, let me die of the bastinado.

div2.stage: Enter Duke Ferneze, Angelo, and other Nobles attendants.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: Lords, make a stand, I wonder that our Son glads not our wished arrival with his presence.

sp.speaker: Aug.
sp.l: No doubt my Lord, his honourable care, Is not acquainted with your sudden landing.

sp.speaker: Duk.
sp.l: We take it so, and whilst ourself in person Enquire the cause, attend us in the Hall, Little thinks he his father is so near, But unexpected, I will go startle him, And put his wit unto the present trial.

sp.speaker: Pag.
sp.l: where is the Prince?

sp.speaker: Io.
sp.l: my most honoured Lord? In private conference with an English post.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: An English post?

sp.speaker: Io.
sp.l: An English post my Lord: the effect of his letters I know, not but I heard him begin a most strange discourse.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: Of what I prithee?

sp.speaker: Io.
sp.l:
Please your honour take a turn or two, I shall relate
(quickly my Lord) he reports there fell such an Inundation of waters in the month of July, about the third of dog-days, that the Owers and Scullers that use to work in the Thames, rowed over houses and landed their fairs in the middle Isle of Paules.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: Is it possible?

sp.speaker: Io.
sp.l: Very easily possible ('sfoot quickly) and more the fishermen that rid between Douer and Calis, took red spurlin, and she Mackerel in the midst of the Exchange,which made mutton so cheap and stale, that it is thought the better half of the townsmen will run horn mad about it.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: It cannot be.

sp.speaker: Io.
sp.l: Not be? why look you sir,

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: Nay.

sp.speaker: Io.
sp.l:
But hear the conclusion, just on Saint Lukes day coming shall be a twelve-month, Westminster and Winchester, drinking a quart of wine together on Salisbury-playne fell into hard words and strange terms, there was thou knave and I knave, and such foul words, as if tow young Barristers had been breathing their wits for a wager, ('sfoot make an end) now it was thought Westminster stood most upon his terms, yet in the end Winchester got one of his best terms from him spite on his teeth,which so vexed Westminster,
that it grew to a deadly feud,which was so hotly pursued that the taking up of the matter cost many broken heads.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: How.

sp.speaker: Ju.
sp.l: So sir, ('sfoot not done yet?) and had not Charing-crosse a tall bow legged Gent: taken up the matter, it is thought Westminster stones would have been too hot for some of them: and in parting the fray, Charing-crosse got such a box on the ear, that he will carry it to his deathsday, some say he got a wry neck by parting the fray, marry Winchester says flatly, he got a crick in his neck, with looking westward for Termers.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: Thou shouldst have told me.

sp.speaker: Iu.
sp.l: Of the English post: why look you my Lord, the post coming in post-haste to show his duty to the Prince, stumbled at a post that lay in his way and broke his sinister shank, and so I break off my discourse and bid your honour welcome home.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: What a strange tale is here? of floods and hills of Charing-crosse, Terms, and I know not what? and when I looked for the conclusion. He breaks off all and leaves me in a Cloud.
There is some trick in it, honoured Iulio?

sp.speaker: Iu.
sp.l: Health to my Sovereign.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: How fares our Son? Have your inducements drawn him from his humour?

sp.speaker: Iu.
sp.l: Faith my Lord I have done a childes part, and almost spent a childes part, to draw him to society, but it is labour lost.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: What is his business with the English post?

sp.speaker: Iu.
sp.l: The English post my Lord? your grace is merry.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: His boy informed me he held conference, About serious matters with an English post.

sp.speaker: Iu.
sp.l: Alas my Lord, the boy is lunatic.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: How lunatic? and before god methought He told a mad discourse, but the occasion.

sp.speaker: Iu.
sp.l: I tell you my Lord, coming abruptly as your honour or any else may do to the Princes chamber, about some ordinary service, he found him in his study, and a company of bottle-nosed Devils dancing the Irish hay about him,which on the sudden so startled the poor boy, as he clean lost his wits, and ever since talks thus idle, as your Excellence hath heard him

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: But tell me doth my son converse with Devils?

sp.speaker: Iu.
sp.l:
As familiarly as you and I, they are his only company keepers, when he hath been dulled at his
study, I have known a Devil and he play at Ticktack for phillips, by the whole day together.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: It is passing strange, but may we without danger go near his study?

sp.speaker: Iu.
sp.l: At your honour's pleasure,
See where he sits, be Patient and observe.

sp.speaker: Po.
sp.l: prevented still? now by Medusaes snakes, And black Erinnis ever burning lamp, If all the skill in pyromantic rules, Deep Aeromancy, or the precious soul, Of Germanic spells and Characters Graven in the surface of our mother earth, Can work this strange achievement,

sp.speaker: Aug.
sp.l: How his brain sweats in pursuit of learning

sp.speaker: Duk.
sp.l: O attend.

sp.speaker: Poly.
sp.l: The first house is vulgarised, the Horoscope or Angle of the Orient, and his Ascendant betokeneth beginning of life, Merchandise, marriage and ---

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: Let us break him off.

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.l: So please your excellence.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.l:
The second and third house, the third House is cadent from the Angle of the Orient, and Ascendant to the Angle Septentrionall; signifying Fathers Sisters and Daughters absent and lost, Daughters and fathers lost: here then I find my demand, the Maid lost my
Sister, thus then I proportion my figure, there I place my witnesses, and here my Judge, and thus proceed to the Invocation.

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.l: Renowned Prince, Prince Polymetes, zounds Prince.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.l: Discourteous Iulio, give my study leave.

sp.speaker: Ju.
sp.l: Heart not a jot, the Duke your father.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.l: I will make my father joyful by my toil, Had not thy folly interrupted me, My hopes ere this had met their period.

sp.speaker: Au.
sp.l: Your princely father.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.l: O torment me not with his remembrance.

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.l: 'sblood he is safe returned.

sp.speaker: Poly.
sp.l: O would he were, then should not Genozes Crown, For want of strong supportance be pressed down. Is it not enough, that like a harmless Prince Spending my hours in Contemplation, I let you hold the rains of government. Unfit for me, my father hath a deep And searching judgment that can brush and sweep such idle brained and antique Parasites, Forth of his presence, pray your absence,

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l:
I can but smile to see how Protheus like, They turn the shape of their discourse and project, Thinking to lead me in an idle maze,
after their folly, well, I will temporise, and note the issue, come my Lords let us in, His humour is grounded, and like subtle fire: The more suppressed, it mounts so much the higher.

sp.speaker: Iu.
sp.l: Why so, this jest came smoothly off and was not soiled in the working

sp.speaker: Po.
sp.l: That boy is worth his weight in pearl, didst mark what a tale of a Cock and a Bull, he told my father whilst I made thee and the rest away, by a bill of Conveyance at his back?

sp.speaker: Iu.
sp.l: And I did simple Knights seruire in persuading the Duke the boy was lunatic.

sp.speaker: Po.
sp.l: it was admirable, doth not this jest deserve to be chronicled?

sp.speaker: Iu.
sp.l: No by my troth, yet I must needs say, some as bad have been, for howsoever our practise pass currant with your father for the present, our villainies must needs break forth, they are so notorious and public.

sp.speaker: Po.
sp.l:
No matter let them, have not we brains? brains and they be well minced are sauce for any meat, let mine uncle turn Turxe and break forth, let the whole town turn cuckold and blow their horns in our disgrace, I have brains, let the Sun and the seven Stars be opposed, I have brains for that too my present wit shall give them all the lie in their
throats, and maintain it at pocket, dagger, and pistol when I have done.

sp.speaker: Iu.
sp.l: A mourner boy? what solemn funeral, Hath hung that sable livery on thy back?

sp.speaker: Pa.
sp.l: Her death my Lord that hath cut out the like, For both your honours, the Countess is deceased.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.l: Then will my uncle be a heavy mourner. But how the manner of her death?

sp.speaker: Pa.
sp.l: I will tell your honour that hereafter and give you the ground of an admirable jest.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.l: And we play not true moles and work it out of the ground, let me die of the green sickness.

sp.speaker: Iu.
sp.l: The ground then comes?

sp.speaker: Pa.
sp.l: No I will tell you that in private, the life of a jest thrives in the first revealing, it concerns the manner of your aunt's death and a law-trick of your uncle.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.l: Come to the solemn rites, and weep at least those being ended wewill receive your jest.

div2.stage: Solemnpe Musique to a funerall song the Horse borne ouer the stage, Duke Lurdo, Polymetes, Angelo, Iulio, Horatio and mouners &c.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l:
What is a man; heart-a-the-Deuill mere fools, His rich invention, Machiuilian plots: Idle illusive antic fantasies. Apelles grapes, I had as full a brain, Fertile invention and as forward hopes, As man could father, or his wit bring forth: Yet in a minute in bubbles age,
The venomed fury of a bitter spleen, Confounded all, forgetful that I was, Women are moulded out of bashfulness: And must be drawn to kindness by degrees. All this I knew.

sp.speaker: Lur.
sp.l: Neither the Law nor I, Know any reason why Horatio. But mum, Law-tricks as closely as I can; Mine ear shall drink his meditation.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: Had she survived Time ---

sp.speaker: Lur.
sp.l: Might have found us out, Good, firm in Law, I am a fool to doubt, His constant secrecy.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: But now she is dead.

sp.speaker: Lur.
sp.l: The deepest wit could not have bettered, Our smooth conveyance, but upright and straight, Unknown, unseen, I will work upon conceit.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l:
Had she been living, golden promises, The smooth Attorneys to a Lovers tongue Might have in time solicited my suite, Gifts might have pleaded, mournful Elegies, Told her my passions, had she been composed Of steel or flint, nay, made of women's hearts, The most obdurate mettle, Time and Art&H0;, But she is dead, O hell! and in her tomb.
My hopes are buried.

sp.speaker: Lur.
sp.l: My conceited brain, Hath an odd crotchet called me back again.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: To all these bad misfortunes should the Count use any tricks?

sp.speaker: Lur.
