sp.l: Ha? he talks of tricks, Of count and tricks, for tricks and count are twins.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: Yet I regard not.

sp.speaker: Lur.
sp.l: I am right and straight.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: Say he complain?

sp.speaker: Lur.
sp.l: Suppose he tell the Duke he gave the poison.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: He contrived her death, and cannot wrong me,

sp.speaker: Lur.
sp.l: Fie, I fear him not, He doth but father, what my brain begot.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: This comfort yetwhich many want I have, To follow my fair fortunes to the grave.

div2.head: ACTUS QUINTUS.
div2.stage: Enter Horatio's Page With a Theeues Lanthorne.

sp.speaker: Page.
sp.l: O, shall I venture? ha, shall I enter? Shield me Appollo, the ground it so hollow That every step I tread upon it, Methinks it sings a dead man's Sonnet. Fates, O Fates be honest Drabs, Fear gives me ten thousand stabs, I dare not further it is wilful murther, Thus late to tread the cloister vaults. For though I am small, I have great men's faults, Then gentle Fates, take some remorse, I watch an honest, kind, quick course. Grant that no Hobgoblins fright me, No hungry devils rise up and bite me: No Urchin, Elves, or drunkards Ghosts, Shove me against walls or posts, O grant I may no black thing touch, Though many men love to meet such. But here is the tomb, my hopes sufficing, I watch a dainty Duck's uprising, Her cheeks now are chilly, as is the pale lily, But when her eye uncloses, they will look like two fair Roses

A light my master? or some sprite, Yet What need Devils have candle-light, It is he, all hid, I will not be seen,
For once this tomb shall be my screen. He hides himself.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: I cannot rest, my guilt keeps ope mine eyes. My passion rips my bosom, and my blood Is turned to poisoned water, and so swells, That my vexed soul, endures a thousand hells. If I chance slumber, then I dream of Serpents, Toads, altogether, and such venomous evils, As hale me from my sleep like forked Devils, Midnight, thou AEthiope, Empress of black souls, Thou general Bawd to the whole world, I salute thee, Wishing thy poison dropped upon my brain, For my so rude, so rash, so heedless murther, In the ambition and the height of lust, Not giving my blood liberty to cool. To poison such a beauty, O black Fate! Thus many killed, too soon repent too late. Soft, stay, this sames the chilly monument, That hugs her body in his marble arms. Thou gentle soul of my deceased love; O, wert but possible to enjoy thy voice, Thy sweet Harmonious voice, I should be blessed, But Even to dally with thy syllables, O tomb.

sp.speaker: Pa.
sp.l: No tomb but Cistern filled with tears.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: O heart!

sp.speaker: Pa.
sp.l: No heart, but sink of grief and fears.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: Countess, soul shadow, shadow speak again.

sp.speaker: Pa.
sp.l: Speak again.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: What should I speak, my hate, or thy huge wrongs?

sp.speaker: Pa.
sp.l: Huge wrongs.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: Huge wrongs indeed, but charitable soul, What ransom shall I pay thee for thy life?

sp.speaker: Pa.
sp.l: Thy life.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: My life?

sp.speaker: Pa.
sp.l: Aye, Aye life.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: Discourteous air, My blood is frozen with despair.

sp.speaker: Pag.
sp.l: Despair.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: Pardon forgive me, shall I go?

sp.speaker: Pa.
sp.l: I go.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: But shall your hate pursue me, Aye or no?

sp.speaker: Pa.
sp.l: No.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: Adieu my grief and I will go sleep.
Pray God my tongue can my heart's ease counsel keep

sp.speaker: Pa.
sp.l:
Ha? are you vanished? let me see, he may be fallen asleep against some pillar, for I will be sworn a talked very idly, Abiit decessit euasit erupit, I would fain know that Wag that can put me down for a woman's Ghost extempore, especially if it were to be performed under
a tomb cloth, but here lay the desperate venture, had she chanced to have risen, and spoke before her cue, as about this time she must tice, or my sleepy drink plays, the drowsy companion with her.
Heart a me, my master again, what cross points are these? I see I must betake me to my late refuge.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: It was no Ghost, subtle opinion, Working in man's decayed faculties, Cuts out and shapes illusive fantasies, And our weak apprehensions like wax, Receive the form, and presently convey Unto our dull imagination. And hereupon we ground a thousand lies, As that we see Devils rattling their chains, Ghosts of dead men, variety of spirits, When our own guilty conscience is the hell. and our black thoughts, the Caverns where they dwell: Yet sure this was her shadow, for I hear Her last words sound still dancing in mine ear. Then gentle soul, if thou beest yet unthroned, Answer one question and no more.

sp.speaker: Pag,
sp.l: No more?

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: May my heart's ease true repentance satisfy, My wilful, murther, your reply.

sp.speaker: Pa.
sp.l: Aye.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: Thanks, thousand and thanks, and so farewell.

sp.speaker: Po.
sp.l: Farewell.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: The bane of murder is despair and hell.

sp.speaker: Pa.
sp.l: Was ever poor little knave put to his last trumps as I am? what shall I do now; my heart goes pit a pat in my belly like a pair of washing beetles, should he return again now, as my hand to a Lobster-pie he will, all the Fat were in the fire, but hark it is one a clock, and just about this minute she should play the wagtail and stir.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.l: What trance was this? where am I?

sp.speaker: Pa.
sp.l: O she speaks, Fates and be good girls keep my master away, and let his man have a little sport with his mistress.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.l: What place is this? am I in heaven or no.

sp.speaker: Pa.
sp.l: No.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.l: What voice is that? is this place earth?

sp.speaker: Pa.
sp.l: Earth.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.l: Earth? how came I hither? do I live again?

sp.speaker: Pa.
sp.l: Live again.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.l: What voice is that? a woman or some youth?

sp.speaker: Pa.
sp.l: Youth.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.l: My fears will murther me, my powers are frighted.

sp.speaker: Pa.
sp.l: Alas poor stirring ghost art over spirited.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.l: Boy.

sp.speaker: Pa.
sp.l: mistress.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.l: Tell me.

sp.speaker: Pa.
sp.l: all and more anon. The sleepy drink hath played the honest man,

sp.speaker: Cou.
sp.l: What sleepy drink? how came I in this tomb?

sp.speaker: Pa.
sp.l: I will tell you that in a more private room, Away I will tell you a strange wonder, Then winters lightning, or Christmas thunder, Then to my fathers trip and go, Nimble prevention on it runs woe.

div2.stage: Enter Ferneze the Duke, Count, Lurdo, Angelo, Horatio and Adam with others atendant.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: No more of mourning brother, we have laid Our timeless sorrows in a quiet grave, When men inter their comfort let them weep: Not when their crying charm is laid to sleep.

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.l: Great Duke mine eyes are not thus great with tears, For our griefs funeral, but that her shame, And future scandal will out live her name,

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: Come let mirth kill it, and to your discourse, Is our son grown unto that height of riot Your speeches intimate.

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.l:
Your highness knows, I know the law, if I have wronged the Prince, I stand in compass of a præmonire, And he by writ of ad quod dampuum may,
sue his recovery, I know the law.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: Nay his own letter partly grants as much, But note his subtle reason, here he writs, That of set purpose he laid by himself, And played the part of a wild prodigal, Only to put your love unto the test, Onwhich advantage to egress his wealth, You did endear him to society, Of careless wantons and light Courtesans, Made secret vaults and cellars under ground.

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.l: Non tenet in bocardo I demur, Do but send out your Iterum summoneas , Or capias vt legatum to attach, And bring him viua voce tongue to tongue, And vi et armis I will revenge this wrong.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: Leave that to trial, here he further writes, That by his skill and practise in black Art, He hath found out and by much toil redeemed, My daughter from the Turkish servitude.

sp.speaker: Lo.
sp.l: Redeemed your daughter! an apparent error, Which you by way of melius inquerendum . May soon discuse, he ransom home your daughter As sure as I made cellars under ground, Or played his pander.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l:
Howsoever it prove,
I mean to try the utmost of his wit, To see how quaintly he can bear himself: But who comes here.

sp.speaker: Ad.
sp.l: Marry my good Lord, this is the green bur, that stuck so close to the young Princes sleeve, the shoemakers cutting knife, that fitted his boots to the prodigals last.

sp.speaker: Lo.
sp.l: If I be Compos mentis, this is she, Must play your daughters part, my Lord beware, Work close cock sure, I see the gin the snare.

sp.speaker: Em.
sp.l: Most reverend father.

sp.speaker: Lo.
sp.l: Father? now it fits, Ware an old Fox, Duke I have brains I have wits.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: Immodest impudent and shameless girl, Is it not enough thou hast misled my son, And wrong his reputation?

sp.speaker: Em.
sp.l: How wronged him father? I must needs say I have played Will&H0; with the wisp with my brother and have led him up and down the maze of good fellowship, till I have made his wit and his wealth both turn sick but for any other wrong, I appeal to himself, my uncle honest Iulios where is he? and all the rest of this good Audience, therefore pray good father.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: Out of my sight, thou art no child of mine,

sp.speaker: Em.
sp.l:
You are the more beholding to some of your neighbours,
tut ma look on me well, here is your own nose, and thick kissing lip up and down, if my mother were living, she would never buss you more, till you confessed I were your daughter.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: What an audacious naughty pack is this? Have her before a Justice, Adam.

sp.speaker: Em.
sp.l: Do, with all my heart good father, send me to a Justice, for a pretty woman with a smooth tongue and an Angel's voice, can do much with Justice in this golden age, but thus much before I go, if Justice will not provide me a better father, I will have you, or I will give the beadle of the ward a fee to cry, a new father a new, as they do oysters at Callais.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: Brother are you acquainted with this woman?

sp.speaker: Lo.
sp.l: I must needs say that at my nephews suite, I gave her a months lodging and her diet. But Nuda veritate in bare truth, and bona fide without circumstance, Splendeuse Sole the bright Sun never saw, A wench more capable of wit and law, And how soever she is with beauty graced, I dare engage mine honour she is chaste,

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l:
I give your words good credit, yet it is rare, to find a woman wanton, chaste and fair, But now unto my son, whose powerful art&H0;,
Strives to ungive his sisters servitude. Polimetes in his study.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.l: Thanks He eat, thou hast ensphered my hope In a gold circle, o were my father here, This fight would of his age bate twenty year.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: What sight my son.

sp.speaker: Po.
sp.l: Lend me your watery eye, That swims in passion for my sisters loss, And in this book prospective, let it read, A pleasing lecture.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: I conceive two shapes. A civil merchant and a beauteous maid. Their pace is speedy and my slower eye, Cannot keep way with their celerity.

sp.speaker: Po.
sp.l: That maid is my sister, whom on magics wing, To this fair presence, my rich art shall bring, Prepare to meet them, for this minutes age, sends with my charm their airy pilgrimage.

div2.stage: Enter Iulio like a Marchant, and Ioculo like a Lady.

sp.speaker: Iu.
sp.l: Wherever are we now? how strangely were we born Upon the pinions of the fleeting air, And where dismounted? unto what great Prince Christian or Pagan longs this mansion.

sp.speaker: Io.
sp.l: Are we in any sociable place? Or in the Cell of some Magician, Who by his skill in hellish exorcisms, Made us his thrall?

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: I can forbear no longer, Welcome thrice welcome.

sp.speaker: Iu.
sp.l: Welcome?

sp.speaker: Io.
sp.l: Whence?

sp.speaker: Iu.
sp.l: To whom?

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: To me.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.l: to us.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: Thy father.

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.l: and thy friends.

sp.speaker: Io.
sp.l: do not beguile us, O Demetrio? We are betrayed, see the Magician, That by his cunning and strong working charms, Brought us unknown.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: Into thy fathers arms, Welcome Emilia, with this Ivory chain, I sphære my hopes and in thy bosom rain, These tears of comfort, then embrace thy friends. Thy Brothers Art all further difference ends.

sp.speaker: Io.
sp.l: Your City.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: Genoa.

sp.speaker: Io.
sp.l: And your reverend name.

sp.speaker: Duk.
sp.l: Ferneze.

sp.speaker: Io.
sp.l: Father.

sp.speaker: Lur.
sp.l:
Yes the very same, I do remember when she went to nurse,
What a cursed vixen it was, but now she is grown.

sp.speaker: Io.
sp.l: Not past all goodness, yet I hope sir: but i'faith Brother wast you that brought us from Turky a cock-horse? and your Genoan hackney be so quick paced you shall have more of our Custom.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: Lay by discourse, what Gentleman is that comes uninvited to our feast of joy.

sp.speaker: Ioc.
sp.l: Pray welcome him father, he is a Genoan merchant, that with much suite ransomed me from the Turke.

sp.speaker: Duk.
sp.l: My hopes redeemer welcome, but proceed Unto the doubtful fortunes of my child: It was told me she was stolen from Monta sancta.

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.l: You help my memory, thence she was stolen, And for her beauty, chosen Concubine To the lascivious Turke, but by much suit, And meditation of some special friends, I bought her freedom with a thousand marks.

sp.speaker: Duk.
sp.l:
Which wewill repay with ample interest, Once more wewill bid you welcome, and to set A smoother gloss upon our merriment, There is a quick Wench that only lives by wit, Who understanding I had lost my Daughter, Borrowed thy habit, and Usurps thy name, One call her in, now Daughter make thee fit,
To combat and dismount her active wit.

sp.speaker: Lur.
sp.l: A parlous Girl, her wits a mere Snaphaunce, Goes with a fire lock, she strikes fire from stones, She knows the Law too, a mere murthering piece, Fight low, lock close, she speaks mere, lightning Niece.

sp.speaker: Em.
sp.l: How now father, have you put on your considering Cap, and bethought you? or shall I proceed and traverse my writ of errors?

sp.speaker: Lur.
sp.l: Ha, writ of errors? Law-tricks, words of Art&H0; Demurs and quillets.

sp.speaker: Em.
sp.l: All not worth a pin, will you bethink you father?

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: I have bethought me, and to let thee see, The true proportion of thy impudence, Behold my Daughter, whom thou personatest.

sp.speaker: Em.
sp.l: How, your Daughter?

sp.speaker: Ioc.
sp.l: Yes minx, his Daughter.

sp.speaker: Lur.
sp.l: My niece, and I will make it good.

sp.speaker: Em.
sp.l: Pretty i'faith, have ye any more of these tricks? I may be out-faced of myself with a Card often, but i'faith Uncle, the best knave in the bunch, nor all the law in your Budget cannot do it, and as for you Sisley bumtrinkets, I will have about with you at the single Stackado are you a woman?

sp.speaker: Io.
sp.l: No.

sp.speaker: Em.
sp.l: What then?

sp.speaker: Io.
sp.l: A Maid.

sp.speaker: Iu.
sp.l: If his tongue falter, all our plots bewrayed.

sp.speaker: Em.
sp.l: If a true maid, lend a true maid your hand.

sp.speaker: Ioc.
sp.l: Both hand and heart

sp.speaker: Em.
sp.l: The like of me command, Now I conjure thee by the love You bear Dianaes silent Grove, By Cupids bow, and golden arrow, Venus Dove, and chirping Sparrow, By all those vows, the listening winds, Hear when Maids unclasp their minds. By those sweet oaths men use in bed, Besieging of a Maiden head. I do conjure you fore these Lords, To answer truly to my words.

sp.speaker: Io.
sp.l: By these and more, by all the scapes Of amorous Ioue and Phoebus rapes, By Lovers sweet, and secret meetings, Hand embracings and lip-greetings, I promise you before these Lords, To answer truly to your words.

sp.speaker: Em.
sp.l: Where were you born?

sp.speaker: Ioc.
sp.l: In Genoa.

sp.speaker: Em,
sp.l: Your name?

sp.speaker: Ioc.
sp.l: Emilia.

sp.speaker: Em.
sp.l: Lie not.

sp.speaker: Ioc.
sp.l: It were open shame to lie before so many.

sp.speaker: Em.
sp.l: In what Art&H0; were you instructed?

sp.speaker: Ioc.
sp.l: That is not in my part.

sp.speaker: Po.
sp.l: Say music.

sp.speaker: Em.
sp.l: Quickly.

sp.speaker: Io.
sp.l: I was taught to sing, Unto the Lute, and Court each amorous string With a soft finger.

sp.speaker: Em.
sp.l: Good, how many springs Lived you in Monta Santa?

sp.speaker: Ioc.
sp.l: zounds this stings.

sp.speaker: Em.
sp.l: How many?

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.l: Nine.

sp.speaker: Po.
sp.l: zounds ten.

sp.speaker: Io.
sp.l: Ten fops.

sp.speaker: Em.
sp.l: Nay quick.

sp.speaker: Ioc.
sp.l: Twixt nine and ten.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: Right, answer.

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.l: In the nick.

sp.speaker: Em.
sp.l: Your age?

sp.speaker: Io.
sp.l: What?

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.l: Anything.

sp.speaker: Em.
sp.l: Come, fie, you linger.

sp.speaker: Io.
sp.l: I am just as old.

sp.speaker: Em.
sp.l: As what?

sp.speaker: Io.
sp.l: my little finger.

sp.speaker: Em.
sp.l: You dally

sp.speaker: Iu.
sp.l: Sixteen.

sp.speaker: Po.
sp.l: Eighteen.

sp.speaker: Io.
sp.l: Eighteen fools,

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: Nay if you prompt wewill hiss you forth the schools.

sp.speaker: Em.
sp.l: Come your reply, nay quick your certain age,

sp.speaker: Io.
sp.l: I am just as old as --- true Emilaes page.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: A page?

sp.speaker: An.
sp.l: Disguised?

sp.speaker: Ad.
sp.l: Wrapped in a woman's smock?

sp.speaker: Io.
sp.l: I am in a wood.

sp.speaker: Em.
sp.l: And I can spring a cock,

sp.speaker: Iu.
sp.l: Woodcock of our side:

sp.speaker: Em.
sp.l: And you bill so fair, Make a clear glade, I will single forth a pair.

sp.speaker: Po.
sp.l: Fie her wit scalds.

sp.speaker: Lur.
sp.l: We shall have change of weather.

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.l: Cocks of one hen, come prince, let us hold together.

sp.speaker: Em.
sp.l: I thought we should find a Counterfeit of you

sp.speaker: Io.
sp.l:
Then nail me to your lips with a kiss, and make
me currant payment.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: What, young Orlando? how does Charing-Crosse? Is Westminster yet friends with Winchester?

sp.speaker: Po.
sp.l: zounds Iulio now.

sp.speaker: Jo.
sp.l: Alas my Lord, it was a mere device to ---

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.l: Make your Highness merry, when I heard You were returned without your wished Adventure.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: O Master Merchant, you adventured well, To cheat yourself thus of a thousand marks,

sp.speaker: Em.
sp.l: How now my Lord?

sp.speaker: Lur.
sp.l: Nay, I will but see your breast, mine eyes desire, No lower object.

sp.speaker: Em.
sp.l: Go to, read your errors.

sp.speaker: Lur.
sp.l: I cannot now return, non est inuenta, Brother embrace your child, your second heir, I found firm witness in her bosom bare.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: Art thou Emilia?

sp.speaker: Em.
sp.l: Emelia, your Daughter, once a Turkish prisoner

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: Receive a joyful blessing rise and say, What wit or power freed thee.

sp.speaker: Em.
sp.l: Dear father, the manner both of my enlarging and captiving I will relate, when more convenient time and place shall incite me, but upon this occasion, pray give me leave to put my brother beside his melancholy

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: I prithee do so.

sp.speaker: Em.
sp.l: Why how now Student? grand Magician, Puritane, come, you never played the Wag, You know not Winefrides hem, not the Counts vault.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: A'mort man? what, can Polymetes daunt? Hath he not Hyren here?

sp.speaker: Po.
sp.l: zounds all will out, brains ---

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: Now for a hundred dozen of Larks to make a pie of the brains.

sp.speaker: Po.
sp.l: Well, done it was, and out it must.

sp.speaker: Du,
sp.l: Why how now Polymetes in a dump? Where is your Venetian Merchant and your Sister?

sp.speaker: Po.
sp.l: Who? Emilia? why look you here father, do you think I knew her not? ask the Boy and Iulio, do you think I would have maintained her as I did but only for affinities sake? what said I at first Nuncle? did I not urge affinities? and you would see me hanged say and I did not urge affinity?

sp.speaker: Em.
sp.l: And yet you pleaded hard for a nights lodging.

sp.speaker: Poly.
sp.l: Only to try thy honesty by this Element, ask my uncle else?

div2.stage: Enter Horatioes Page and whisper with Polimetes.

sp.speaker: Em.
sp.l: He is a sweet womanist.

sp.speaker: Lur,
sp.l: No more of that, niece you are a wag.

sp.speaker: Em.
sp.l: Well said old water Rat, But that my brother Conjurer should fail, In the black Art&H0;. ---

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.l: In the black Pudding: pish, Of all arts else, only the law is firm.

sp.speaker: Em.
sp.l: And yet that danceth changes every Term.

sp.speaker: Po.
sp.l: Well ieston gallants, and uncle, you that make a pish at the black Art&H0;, my books to the piece of Arras, where Venus and Adonis stood kissing and the cuckoldly pander Vulcan watched them, and all your by-ways to boot, I raise up my Aunt your late wife in the same proportion, habit and gesture, she usually wore in her life time.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: Do that, I will swear there is virtue in thy Art&H0;.

sp.speaker: Po.
sp.l:
And if I do not, say Philosophy is foolery, Logic legerdemain, and Conjuring mere cony catching, as indeed it is. And now by virtue of this wand, Each in his circle keep his stand, Now Belioll and Astaroth, Sole commanders of the North, By Hecates head, Erinnis snakes, Styx and all infernal Lakes, I charge you kneel to Proserpine, And by her licence all divine Dismiss the Countess from those shades, Where pleasure springs and never fades. Festina, cito, citius, come
free Tenant of Elizium.

div2.stage: Enter Countesse, she writes a little, throwes downe the paper and departs.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: The Count looks pale.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.l: why starts Horatio?

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.l: . What wrote the shadow?

sp.speaker: Po.
sp.l: That, these lines will show, Horatio, base Horatio poisoned me, I was your sister, right mine injury.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: Horatio?

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.l: Yes, Horatio poisoned her Revenge it Duke be a true Justicer.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: Revenge it I will, degenerous homicide, What reason led thee to so damned a deed?

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: I loved her, wood her, my hot love denied Changed into hate, I poisoned her, she died.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: Sounds this like truth.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: And if you think I lie, Ask Lurdo, his damned tongue will answer I.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: Had he a hand in it?

sp.speaker: Lur.
sp.l: No, I will demur.

sp.speaker: Ad.
sp.l: Revenge it Duke, be a true Justicer.

sp.speaker: Lur.
sp.l: He gave the poison.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: And you laid the plot

sp.speaker: Ad.
sp.l: Knit up two villains in one riding knot.

sp.speaker: Poly.
sp.l: What quillet now?

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.l: At non plus.

sp.speaker: Em.
sp.l: Senseless, mute? Silence cries guilty, he lets fall the suite.

sp.speaker: Lur., Hor.
sp.l: Our sentence guilty,

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: Then be this your doom, You shall be closed alive in her dead tomb.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.l: Urge a reprieve:

sp.speaker: Lur.
sp.l: Our punishment defer,

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: No, we must be an upright Justicer; To the execution.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: Do, the world shall prove My heart is as bold to die as it was to love.

sp.speaker: Lur.
sp.l: Byrlady so is not mine, I would give my goods, For a good habeas Corpus, to remove me Into another Country.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: Leave demurs, Close them into that grave, that dead man's Inn, Pity true virtue should be lodged with sin.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: Make room dear Madam, law this leave doth give To die by thee with whom I could not live,

sp.speaker: Lur.
sp.l: And wronged Countess though I hated thee, I come to take my latest sleep with thee. Countess in the Tomb.

sp.speaker: Cou.
sp.l: Kind thou art welcome, and shalt ever have, My arms thy winding sheet, my breast thy grave.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: Sister?

sp.speaker: Po.
sp.l: Aunt?

sp.speaker: Em.
sp.l: Madam?

sp.speaker: Lur.
sp.l: My much wronged wife?

sp.speaker: Cou.
sp.l: Justice great Duke, give me my husbands life, Both his and his, if your demand be why, See she survives for whose death they should die.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: Alive.

sp.speaker: Lur.
sp.l: Unblemished.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: 'sblood I gave her poison.

sp.speaker: Pa.
sp.l: I could tell your honour a tale in your ear to the contrary, I must needs say your will was good, but my father being your drug-seller, instead of a deadly poison, gave you a sleepy potion, do you remember the Echo at the tomb? though I played the knave with you, I did like an honest man with her.

sp.speaker: Lur.
sp.l: Thou didst indeed, and I will requite thee well.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.l: How now Uncle? what think you of Scholarship now?

sp.speaker: Lur.
sp.l: As of the law, good as it may be used, But to my wife.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: Brother, I will speak your part, Receive her, love, and lodge her in your heart.

sp.speaker: Lur.
sp.l: Nocte dieque.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: What shall I do then?

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l:
Justice shall merce thee, and by our command We banish thee the Court, though not our Land,
Your course is virtuous, let your honour grow Till age hath clothed you in a robe of snow. Lastly, thy merit is not trivial, That turned to mirth a Scene so tragical.

sp.speaker: Epilogue.
sp.l: Who would have thought, such strange events should fall Into a course so smooth and comical? Who would have thought such treachery could rest, In such a smooth and virtuous seeming breast? Who would have thought a bud of this young growth, Should out of present wit over-reach us both? And to conclude, who would have thought the ear Of your mild patience would so gently bear With these our weak deserts?which if they please you ought It is less than we desire, more than we thought.
